[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: check_is_full_after_eviction()] [Break Condition] At line 442, loop breaks when !is_full(). Can rounding errors or race conditions cause this to never evaluate to false, creating infinite eviction loop? (High)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: is_full()] [Dual Capacity Check] At line 460, mempool is full if EITHER count >= capacity OR size_bytes >= capacity_bytes. Can attacker exploit this by flooding with small transactions to hit capacity, or large transactions to hit capacity_bytes, whichever is easier? (High)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: gc()] [GC Sort Manipulation] At line 934, gc_txns are sorted by (address, replay_protector). Can attacker craft transactions with specific addresses/replay_protectors to manipulate GC order and prevent specific transactions from being collected? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: gc()] [Parking Range Calculation] At lines 946-957, park_range_end is calculated based on next transaction in GC list. Can attacker exploit this logic by submitting transactions with specific sequence number patterns to avoid parking? (High)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: gc()] [Sequential Transaction Parking] At lines 959-976, transactions after GC'd transaction are parked. Can attacker exploit this by causing specific sequence numbers to be GC'd, forcing legitimate high-value transactions into parking lot indefinitely? (High)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: gc()] [Priority Index Removal During GC] At line 961, priority_index.remove() is called for parked transactions. If transaction is currently being read by consensus, can this cause invalid transaction references or consensus failures? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: gc()] [Timeline Index Panic] At lines 963-970, timeline_index.get_mut() uses unwrap_or_else() with panic. Can attacker trigger this panic by corrupting sender_bucket or causing timeline_index to be missing entries? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: gc_by_expiration_time()] [Eager Expire Abuse] At line 911, gc() is called with eager_expire_time(block_time). Can attacker manipulate block_time or oldest_insertion_time to cause premature or delayed GC, affecting transaction inclusion? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: eager_expire_time()] [Oldest Transaction Search] At lines 885-892, code searches first 20 entries in system_ttl_index for oldest never-parked transaction. Can attacker flood mempool with parked transactions to hide legitimately old transactions, bypassing eager expiration? (High)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: eager_expire_time()] [Age Calculation Overflow] At line 894, SystemTime::now().duration_since() could fail. Can attacker exploit clock manipulation or time travel attacks to cause GC bypass? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: eager_expire_time()] [Saturating Add] At line 897, saturating_add is used. Can attacker cause gc_time + eager_expire_time to saturate at u64::MAX, effectively disabling GC? (High)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: commit_transaction()] [Missing Transaction on Commit] If transaction being committed doesn't exist in mempool (already GC'd or never existed), does commit_transaction() handle this gracefully or cause index inconsistencies? (High)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: commit_transaction()] [Sequence Number Jump Attack] At lines 681-682, new_account_seq_number is calculated as max(current, txn_seq + 1). Can Byzantine validator commit transaction with very high sequence number to cause all future transactions from that account to be rejected? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: reject_transaction()] [Hash Index Mismatch] At lines 717-720, code checks if hash_index matches provided account and replay_protector. Can attacker exploit race conditions where hash_index is updated between check and removal? (High)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: reject_transaction()] [Partial Rejection] At lines 722-726, transaction is removed from transactions HashMap and indexes separately. Can failure in between leave mempool inconsistent? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: commit_transaction()] [Promotion After Commit] At line 689, process_ready_seq_num_based_transactions() is called after commit. Can this promotion fail or be exploited to cause transactions to never become ready? (High)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: read_timeline()] [Batch Size Overflow] At lines 805-817, batch_total_bytes is calculated with saturating_add(). Can attacker craft transactions such that saturation occurs, allowing batch to exceed max_batch_bytes limit? (High)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: read_timeline()] [Timeline ID Manipulation] At lines 786-819, last_timeline_id is updated for each transaction. Can attacker exploit this by causing specific timeline_ids to be set, preventing future transactions from being read? (High)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: read_timeline()] [Reverse Iteration] At line 801, iteration is done in reverse (.rev()). Can this cause transactions to be returned in wrong order, breaking consensus or shared mempool assumptions? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: read_timeline()] [Missing Transaction Handling] At line 804, code checks if transaction exists in mempool. If it doesn't (due to race with GC), is this handled correctly or does it cause batch to be incomplete? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: read_timeline()] [Before Parameter Bypass] At line 798, 'before' parameter is passed to read_timeline(). Can attacker manipulate this timestamp to read/skip specific transactions, affecting consensus ordering? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: timeline_range()] [Range Query Injection] At lines 841-871, timeline_range() takes start_end_pairs HashMap. [File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: insert()] [Size Bytes Calculation] At line 355, size_bytes is incremented by txn.get_estimated_bytes(). If this estimate is inaccurate, can attacker exploit to bypass capacity_bytes limit? (High)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Constant: TXN_INDEX_ESTIMATED_BYTES] [Size Estimation Accuracy] At lines 38-41, estimated per-txn overhead is calculated. If this estimate is too low, can attacker exhaust memory by inserting many transactions that appear small but consume large index space? (High)

[File: aptos-core/mempool/src/core_mempool/transaction_store.rs] [Function: new()] [Capacity Configuration] At lines 132-136, capacity, capacity_bytes, and capacity_per_user are set from config. Can misconfigured values cause mempool to accept too many/few transactions? (Medium)
